author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: Perhaps this is a bit heavy for chat, but I'm wondering how the core devs feel about "the human cost of Ethereum", or "Ethereum is one of the missions of my life", or both of these being true together.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: There is a devcon diary of Greg on Youtube, where he mentions a feeling that there's a transition from a family to a community, and how it feels somewhat different. The culture of Ethereum-adjacency feels to me as rather distinct from those of the wider open source space for instance, and also a little different from the energy of academic economics, and people who like maths and CS, etc. I'm confident these perceptions are particular to me, though I'd love to hear what perceptions others have that they suspect are particular to themselves.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: The recent tweetstorms stemming from Avalanche <> Ethereum relations unlocked quite a lot of energy. It was strangely bliss-evoking to see the latent become the expressed.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: One type of thread that arose was of the sort "here I am, in some part of my home, at some peculiar hour, working on Ethereum".

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: I have witnessed incredible excitement from academics, and seemingly destructive intensities of drive by founders, for instance.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: I suppose the kernal-pursuit of this open-ended waterfall of text is "what is it like to be a deep Etherean", and "what is the true price of Ether".
